    Highlights

    •
    Microbiota controls constitutive IFN-I production by pDCs at steady state
    •
    Tonic IFNAR signaling instructs a basal state of cDCs, poised for future immune combat
    •
    Tonic IFN-I signals license cDCs for T cell priming against harmless peripheral antigens
    •
    Reduced metabolic fitness of Ifnar1−/− cDCs cannot be overcome by direct activation

    Summary

    Environmental signals shape host physiology and fitness. Microbiota-derived cues are required to program conventional dendritic cells (cDCs) during the steady state so that they can promptly respond and initiate adaptive immune responses when encountering pathogens. However, the molecular underpinnings of microbiota-guided instructive programs are not well understood. Here, we report that the indigenous microbiota controls constitutive production of type I interferons (IFN-I) by plasmacytoid DCs. Using genome-wide analysis of transcriptional and epigenetic regulomes of cDCs from germ-free and IFN-I receptor (IFNAR)-deficient mice, we found that tonic IFNAR signaling instructs a specific epigenomic and metabolic basal state that poises cDCs for future pathogen combat. However, such beneficial biological function comes with a trade-off. Instructed cDCs can prime T cell responses against harmless peripheral antigens when removing roadblocks of peripheral tolerance. Our data provide fresh insights into the evolutionary trade-offs that come with successful adaptation of vertebrates to their microbial environment.

    Graphical Abstract

    Keywords

    1. Microbiota
    2. conventional dendritic cells
    3. plasmacytoid dendritic cells
    4. type I interferons
    5. peripheral tolerance

    Introduction

    Border surfaces of multicellular organisms are colonized by a complex ecosystem composed of bacteria, viruses, and fungi, collectively referred to as the microbiota (Blander et al., 2017; Hooper and Macpherson, 2010
    7.
    Blander, J.M. ∙ Longman, R.S. ∙ Iliev, I.D. ...
    Regulation of inflammation by microbiota interactions with the host
    Nat. Immunol. 2017; 18:851-860
    Crossref
    Scopus (453)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    28.
    Hooper, L.V. ∙ Macpherson, A.J.
    Immune adaptations that maintain homeostasis with the intestinal microbiota
    Nat. Rev. Immunol. 2010; 10:159-169
    Crossref
    Scopus (1113)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Microbiota-controlled signaling pathways affect various aspects of host physiology and fitness. For example, we and others have shown that signals of the microbiota are required to calibrate the function of a broad range of mononuclear phagocytes (MPhs), including those residing at non-mucosal sites, such as in spleen, lymph nodes (LNs), and brain. MPhs and microglia of germ-free (GF) mice were unable to produce various cytokines and chemokines upon stimulation, rendering them more susceptible to virus infections (Abt et al., 2012; Erny et al., 2015; Ganal et al., 2012; Ichinohe et al., 2011
    1.
    Abt, M.C. ∙ Osborne, L.C. ∙ Monticelli, L.A. ...
    Commensal bacteria calibrate the activation threshold of innate antiviral immunity
    Immunity. 2012; 37:158-170
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (769)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    18.
    Erny, D. ∙ Hrabě de Angelis, A.L. ∙ Jaitin, D. ...
    Host microbiota constantly control maturation and function of microglia in the CNS
    Nat. Neurosci. 2015; 18:965-977
    Crossref
    Scopus (2302)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    22.
    Ganal, S.C. ∙ Sanos, S.L. ∙ Kallfass, C. ...
    Priming of natural killer cells by nonmucosal mononuclear phagocytes requires instructive signals from commensal microbiota
    Immunity. 2012; 37:171-186
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (386)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    31.
    Ichinohe, T. ∙ Pang, I.K. ∙ Kumamoto, Y. ...
    Microbiota regulates immune defense against respiratory tract influenza A virus infection
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2011; 108:5354-5359
    Crossref
    Scopus (1158)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). On a mechanistic level, signals from the microbiota were needed to remove a chromatin barrier required for the transcription of immune defense genes after ligation of pathogen sensors (e.g., pattern recognition receptors [PRRs] such as Toll-like receptors). Thus, microbiota-generated signals are required to instruct MPhs during the steady state for future immune defense functions. We refer to such a poised state of MPhs as their basal state. The nature of the microbiota-guided signals and the molecular programs that they control in MPhs to establish such a poised state are poorly understood.
    Dendritic cells are a subset of MPhs and are subdivided into plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) and conventional dendritic cells (cDCs). pDCs can produce high levels of type I interferons (IFN-Is) following virus infections and have been linked to the pathogenesis of various autoimmune diseases (Reizis, 2019
    62.
    Reizis, B.
    Plasmacytoid Dendritic Cells: Development, Regulation, and Function
    Immunity. 2019; 50:37-50
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (385)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). cDCs fulfill critical and non-redundant functions in regulating and inducing T cell (Liu et al., 2007; Probst et al., 2014
    42.
    Liu, K. ∙ Waskow, C. ∙ Liu, X. ...
    Origin of dendritic cells in peripheral lymphoid organs of mice
    Nat. Immunol. 2007; 8:578-583
    Crossref
    Scopus (373)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    59.
    Probst, H.C. ∙ Muth, S. ∙ Schild, H.
    Regulation of the tolerogenic function of steady-state DCs
    Eur. J. Immunol. 2014; 44:927-933
    Crossref
    Scopus (42)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and natural killer (NK) cell responses (Lucas et al., 2007
    44.
    Lucas, M. ∙ Schachterle, W. ∙ Oberle, K. ...
    Dendritic cells prime natural killer cells by trans-presenting interleukin 15
    Immunity. 2007; 26:503-517
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (710)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). During an infection, cDCs located at the pathogen entry site take up antigens and transport them to the draining LNs. cDCs are equipped with a plethora of PRRs, the ligation of which leads to cDC activation, cDC maturation (i.e., upregulation of major histocompatibility complexes [MHCs] and co-stimulatory molecules), and the release of inflammatory mediators. By providing all three signals for potent T cell priming, cDCs efficiently translate pathogen recognition by the innate immune system into highly antigen (Ag)-specific adaptive immunity (Janeway, 1989
    33.
    Janeway, Jr., C.A.
    Approaching the asymptote? Evolution and revolution in immunology
    Cold Spring Harb. Symp. Quant. Biol. 1989; 54:1-13
    Crossref
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The benefits of adaptive immunity in vertebrates have come with a substantial trade-off, comprising unwanted immune responses to autoantigens and ubiquitous components of the environment. Numerous mechanisms operating within the mammalian immune system cooperatively form a barrier to such deleterious immune responses, referred to as peripheral tolerance. For example, at the immunological steady state, Ag presentation by cDCs induces T cell tolerance to avoid unwanted immune responses against “self” or against harmless, environmental Ag (Bonifaz et al., 2002; Hawiger et al., 2001; Probst et al., 2003

    Scopus (1131)

    ). However, despite low level expression of co-stimulatory molecules and pro-inflammatory cytokines, resting cDCs can prime CD8+ T cells, when components of the peripheral tolerance machinery are removed (Muth et al., 2012; Schildknecht et al., 2010
    51.
    Muth, S. ∙ Schütze, K. ∙ Schild, H. ...

    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2012; 109:9059-9064

    Schildknecht, A. ∙ Brauer, S. ∙ Brenner, C. ...
    FoxP3+ regulatory T cells essentially contribute to peripheral CD8+ T-cell tolerance induced by steady-state dendritic cells

    ). The signals and molecular networks instructing the basal state of cDCs are largely unknown but have broad ramifications for the pathophysiology and treatment of inflammatory and autoimmune diseases.
    We set out to interrogate on a molecular level the impact of the commensal microbiota on the basal state of cDCs. Using genome-wide profiling of cDCs, we demonstrate that microbiota-controlled IFN-I production by pDCs controlled a distinct transcriptional, epigenetic, and metabolic basal state of cDCs, enabling them to provide a powerful response following pathogen encounter, but at the same time, also permitting priming of unwanted T cell responses at the steady state. The IFN-I-instructed metabolic basal state of cDCs was characterized by enhanced mitochondrial function, and cDCs genetically deficient for the IFNAR were unfit to prime T cells even if cDCs were directly activated.

    Results

    cDCs from Germ-Free Mice Cannot Initiate T Cell Responses during the Steady State

    Previous studies had revealed functional incompetence of cDCs in GF mice during immune responses against viruses (Abt et al., 2012; Ganal et al., 2012; Ichinohe et al., 2011

    Using a transgenic mouse model (dubbed DIETER) allowing for the tamoxifen (TAM)-inducible expression of class I MHC-restricted CD8+ T cell epitopes specifically on cDCs (Probst et al., 2003

However, such basal state is also permissive for priming of CD8+ T cells against harmless antigens, an activity that is normally blunted by barriers of peripheral tolerance.

    Re-colonization of GF Mice with a Model Microbiota Restores cDC Function

    GF mice lack all components of the microbiota. We investigated if colonization of GF mice with bacterial consortia of increasing complexity was sufficient to normalize cDC responsiveness. Mono-colonization of GF mice with one gram-negative bacterium (Escherichia [E.] coli JM83) (Hapfelmeier et al., 2010

Colonization with a stable model microbiota (referred to as sDMDMm2), consisting of 12 defined bacterial species representing five major prokaryote phyla of gut microbial communities (Uchimura et al., 2016

Similar results were obtained when analyzing systemic TNF or IFN-I levels (Figures S1F–S1I). While the data do not exclude that other components of the microbiota may generate signals that prime cDC (and likely broader MPh) function, re-colonization of GF mice with bacterial consortia of increasing complexity progressively restored cDC responsiveness to microbial stimulation.

    Tonic PRR Signaling Is Required to Instruct a Functional Basal State of cDCs

    We wondered if functional priming of cDCs would require sensing of commensal microbes via PRRs. To this end, we employed Myd88−/− Trif−/− Cardif−/− (MyTrCa−/−) mice lacking three major adaptors of the microbe sensing machinery and directly stimulated cDCs via CD40 that activates cDCs independent of these PRR adaptors. MyD88 and TRIF are required for TLR signaling, and CARDIF transduces signals from the RNA sensors RIG-I and MDA5 (Broz and Monack, 2013; Takeuchi and Akira, 2010
    11.
    Broz, P. ∙ Monack, D.M.
    Newly described pattern recognition receptors team up against intracellular pathogens
    Nat. Rev. Immunol. 2013; 13:551-565

    ). cDC1 and cDC2 from mice lacking all three adaptor proteins (MyTrCa−/− mice) (Spanier et al., 2014
    71.
    Spanier, J. ∙ Lienenklaus, S. ∙ Paijo, J. ...
    Concomitant TLR/RLH signaling of radioresistant and radiosensitive cells is essential for protection against vesicular stomatitis virus infection

    ) were largely unresponsive to CD40 stimulation, comparable to GF mice (Figures 1A–1C). Interestingly, serum levels of TNF and IFN-I were also substantially reduced after systemic CD40 stimulation (Figures S1A and S1B). In contrast, cDC responses in MyTr−/− double knockout mice and in Cardif−/− mice were not significantly impaired (Figures 1A–1C, S1A, and S1B).
    Does programming of the cDCs basal state by the microbiota require direct “sensing” of commensal microbial components by cDCs? To explore this, we created mixed bone marrow chimeras by reconstituting lethally irradiated C57BL/6 mice with an equal mixture of MyTrCa−/− DIETER (CD45.2) and wild-type (CD45.1) bone marrow, so that only model Ag-expressing cDCs were MyTrCa−/−. MyTrCa+/+ DIETER (CD45.2) and wild-type (CD45.1) mixed chimeras were used as controls. Upon depletion of CD4+ T cells, induction of Ag presentation on both sets of chimeras led to comparable priming of functional GP33–41-specific CD8+ T cells (Figures 1G and 1H). Thus, direct sensing of commensal microbial molecules by cDCs is not required for their steady-state calibration.
    We next asked if PRR signaling is required at all for priming of CD8+ T cells at the steady state. We generated DIETER mice lacking PRR signaling on all cells by injecting lethally irradiated MyTrCa−/− mice with bone marrow from MyTrCa−/− DIETER mice. In these mice, CD8+ T cell priming upon antigen induction and CD4+ T cell depletion was strongly reduced (Figure 1I). In control chimeras, priming of MyTrCa−/− and MyTrCa+/+ CD8+ T cells was comparable, excluding that the impaired expansion of CD8+ T cells in MyTrCa−/− mice was due to direct signals through these adaptors in T cells (Figure S1J). Thus, functional calibration of cDCs during steady state requires recognition of commensal microorganisms through PRRs utilizing MyD88, TRIF, and/or CARDIF on cells other than cDCs.

    Commensal Microbiota Controls an IFN-I-Stimulated Gene Signature in cDCs

    To obtain insights into microbiota-controlled transcriptional circuits, we performed genome-wide RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) analysis using RNA isolated from unstimulated splenic cDCs of specific pathogen-free (SPF) mice and GF mice (Figure S2A). Gene Ontology (GO) term clustering of the top 100 differentially expressed genes that were most significantly changed between GF and SPF mice contained functional annotations for cytokine responses. Among the genes included in the GO term “Response to Cytokines” were various transcripts associated with IFN-I signaling (e.g., Oas2, Socs2, Itga6, Itgav, Ifi35, Ifi205, Ifitm1, and Il15) that were less expressed by cDCs from GF mice. Gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) confirmed that genes transcriptionally controlled by IFN-I (i.e., interferon-stimulated genes [ISGs]) (Figures 2A and S2B) and by STAT1 (i.e., the major signal transducer downstream of the IFNAR) (Figures S2C and S2D) were expressed at lower levels in cDCs from GF mice, consistent with previous data showing reduced expression of ISGs in peritoneal macrophages and in microglia isolated from GF mice (Abt et al., 2012; Erny et al., 2015

    Microbiota Controls Tonic IFN-I Expression by pDCs

    It has long been recognized that low levels of IFN-I are continuously produced in normal SPF laboratory mice (Bocci, 1980; Gough et al., 2012; Taniguchi and Takaoka, 2001

    41.
    Lienenklaus, S. ∙ Cornitescu, M. ∙ Zietara, N. ...

    We hypothesized that sensing of commensal microbes via PRRs is translated into constitutive IFN-I expression by pDCs. We generated IFN-β reporter mice lacking adaptor proteins for PRRs. Consistent with impaired cDC function observed in MyTrCa−/− mice (Figures 1A–1C and G–I), we observed a dramatic reduction in steady-state IFN-β expression (Figure 2K). Interestingly, depletion of IFN-I-producing pDCs significantly reduced the propensity of cDC to prime CD8+ T cells at steady state (Figures 2L and S2G). Collectively, the results from genome-wide transcriptional profiling, biochemical data, and reporter assays show that the microbiota controls steady-state expression of IFN-I by pDCs likely involving redundant PRR signaling (Figure 2K). cDCs from GF or from pDC-depleted mice show a remarkable absence of an IFN-I-controlled gene expression signature and are functionally impaired.

    Microbiota and IFN-I Control cDC Basal State through a Core Transcriptional Program

    Our data indicate that microbiota-controlled, tonic IFN-I produced by pDCs may be the molecular link between the microbiota and the poised cDC basal state. We extended our genome-wide data by comparing full, steady-state transcriptomes of splenic cDCs isolated from SPF mice, from mice genetically deficient for the α chain of the IFN-I receptor (Ifnar1−/− [SPF] mice), and from GF mice. Pearson correlation (Figure 3A) and principal component analysis (Figure 3B) indicated that cDCs from GF and Ifnar1−/− mice have rather similar transcriptomes that are noticeably different from control cDCs. K-means clustering of differentially expressed genes (false discovery rate [FDR] <0.05) revealed that their majority can be found in clusters (i.e., clusters C1 and C6) markedly increased or decreased expression in both GF and Ifnar1−/− cDCs compared to control cDCs (Figure 3C). Among the most differentially expressed genes in cluster C1, we found several canonical ISGs (Figures 3D and S3A). GSEA analysis for selected interferon-related gene sets revealed a negative correlation for both GF and Ifnar1−/− cDCs (Figure 3E). Interestingly, genes associated with oxidative phosphorylation including genes encoded within the mitochondrial genome were consistently downregulated in cDCs from GF and Ifnar1−/− mice (Figure 3F).
    Splenic cDCs can be divided into two main subpopulations, cDC1 and cDC2, which have been reported to be transcriptionally distinct (Merad et al., 2013
    47.
    Merad, M. ∙ Sathe, P. ∙ Helft, J. ...
    The dendritic cell lineage: ontogeny and function of dendritic cells and their subsets in the steady state and the inflamed setting
    Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2013; 31:563-604
    Crossref
    Scopus (1742)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We obtained transcriptome data from cDC1 and cDC2 from SPF, GF, and Ifnar1−/− mice. Pearson correlation analysis confirmed that cDC1 and cDC2 transcriptomes are distinctly different (Figure 4A). We focused our analysis first on cDC2, because they comprise 80%–90% of all splenic cDCs. Principal-component analysis (PCA) clearly separated the transcriptomes of GF and Ifnar1−/− cDC2 from that of control SPF cDC2 in PC2 (Figure 4B). GO analysis of GO terms with a gene set size from 10 to 1,000 genes classified as biological processes using DAVID revealed that 43 GO terms were enriched at an FDR <0.05 in control cDC2 compared to GF and Ifnar1−/− cDC2 (Table S1). Next, we created an enrichment map where the GO terms were clustered according to overlap of genes (Figure 4C). Although separate clusters could be identified, when the edge cutoff was set to 1, the cluster remained highly interconnected and enriched very similar immunological processes, including two smaller clusters containing IFN-I signaling and function-related GO terms (Figure 4C). This consistent enrichment is caused by more than 35% (81/222) of the genes consistently downregulated in GF and Ifnar1−/− cDC2, where almost 20% (47/222) is represented in more than 5 different GO terms. Thus, a significant proportion of genes consistently downregulated in GF and Ifnar1−/− cDC2 is part of the same immunological process, IFN-I signaling, and function. Using GSEA, in which no prior definition of gene sets is required, we again found a clear negative correlation for selected IFN-I-related gene sets for cDC2 from GF and Ifnar1−/− mice (Figure 4D, dotted lines).
    Such negative correlation in IFN-I-controlled gene sets was obvious also for the comparison of control SPF and Ifnar1−/− cDC1 (Figure 4D). While a negative correlation in GSEA of IFN-I-controlled pathways was not directly evident for cDC1 from GF mice (Figure 4D), it was clearly observed in other, related gene sets such as “Interferon Signaling,” “Interferon Gamma Response,” and “Interferon Gamma Signaling” (Figure S4A). In fact, the genes contained in IFN-γ and IFN-I-controlled gene sets contain many of the same genes and therefore do not strictly discriminate between IFN-I and IFN-γ-controlled genes (Figure S4B). Given this overlap, we were wondering why some interferon-related gene sets enriched in cDC2 but not in cDC1. Part of the reason might relate to the fact that a high fraction of the genes within these gene sets enriched in SPF cDC2 were expressed at much lower levels in SPF cDC1 (Figure S4C) and therefore simply cannot be dramatically downregulated. Collectively, our genome-wide transcriptional profile demonstrated that the most significantly downregulated gene sets in cDC1 and cDC2 from GF and Ifnar1−/− mice are those related to IFN-I signaling.

    Tonic IFN-I Signals Prime cDCs for Subsequent Responses to Microbial Stimulation

    It has been previously postulated that low levels of IFN-I signals during the steady state may be required for responsiveness of the MPh system (Gough et al., 2012; Taniguchi and Takaoka, 2001
    24.
    Gough, D.J. ∙ Messina, N.L. ∙ Clarke, C.J. ...
    Constitutive type I interferon modulates homeostatic balance through tonic signaling
    Immunity. 2012; 36:166-174
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (342)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    77.
    Taniguchi, T. ∙ Takaoka, A.
    A weak signal for strong responses: interferon-alpha/beta revisited
    Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 2001; 2:378-386
    Crossref
    Scopus (425)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). To link steady-state IFN-I to cDC function and to obtain a global understanding of genes that are not upregulated in cDCs from GF or Ifnar1−/− mice following a microbial stimulus, we compared RNA-seq data from LPS-stimulated cDCs isolated from GF, Ifnar1−/−, and control SPF mice. Genes that were significantly less upregulated in cDCs from GF and Ifnar1−/− mice (Figure S5A, marked in red) were submitted to DAVID. Among the top resulting GO terms were “Immune System Process” (p < 2.1e−2) and “Leukocyte Activation” (p < 9.5e−2). GSEA revealed a failure to upregulate the expression of most ISGs and nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) target genes in cDCs from GF and Ifnar1−/− mice after LPS stimulation (Figures 5A, S5B, and S5C). These data link tonic IFN-I signaling during the steady state to a poised cDC state required for effective transcription of ISGs and NF-κB target genes following microbial stimulation.
    In line with our genome-wide data, stimulated cDCs from Ifnar1−/− and GF mice produced significantly less TNF, an NF-κB target gene (Figure 5B). Similar results were obtained for serum levels of TNF (Figure S5D). Such calibration of cDC responsiveness specifically required tonic IFN-I signaling because cDCs deprived of type II (Ifngr−/− mice) or type III IFN signaling (Ifnlr1−/− mice) responded normally (Figure S5E). To exclude that alterations in microbiota composition in Ifnar1−/− mice were causative for the observed functional differences, we investigated cDC responses in co-housed Ifnar1+/+, Ifnar1+/−, and Ifnar1−/−littermates from heterozygous breedings. Only cDCs from co-housed Ifnar1−/− mice showed reduced responsiveness to stimulation (Figures 5C and S5F–S5I). The data largely exclude that altered microbiota in Ifnar1−/− mice is causative for the observed functional differences between cDCs from Ifnar1−/− and control mice.
    While these data link tonic IFN-I to a poised cDC state, they do not directly demonstrate that IFN-I acted on cDCs because of global IFNAR deficiency in Ifnar1−/− mice. We generated mice with cDC-specific IFNAR deficiency by crossing Ifnar1fl/fl mice to Cd11c (Itgax)-Cre mice (Ifnar1ΔDC). Indeed, cDCs from Ifnar1ΔDC mice did not mount an appreciable TNF response to stimulation (Figures 5D and S5J). Of note, Cd11c-Cre targets virtually all mature cDCs in spleen and LNs, whereas only a small fraction of cDC precursors are affected (Caton et al., 2007
    12.
    Caton, M.L. ∙ Smith-Raska, M.R. ∙ Reizis, B.
    Notch-RBP-J signaling controls the homeostasis of CD8- dendritic cells in the spleen
    J. Exp. Med. 2007; 204:1653-1664
    Crossref
    Scopus (676)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Our data demonstrate that mature cDCs require a tonic IFN-I signal provided by pDCs for functional calibration, largely ruling out a dominant effect of IFN-I on cDC precursors that are not or very inefficiently targeted in Ifnar1ΔDC mice.
    Although our data show that both cDCs from GF and Ifnar1−/− mice cannot respond to microbial stimulation, they do not directly proof that the lack of tonic IFN-I signaling is causally linked to the GF phenotype. We addressed this by an array of experiments. First, we generated Ifnar1−/− (GF) mice and compared cDC responsiveness to microbial stimulation in GF and Ifnar1−/− (SPF) mice. Interestingly, cDCs from Ifnar1−/− (GF) mice showed no further reduction in TNF production (Figures 5E and 5F) or IFN-I expression (Figures S5K and S5L) when compared to cDCs from GF or Ifnar1−/− (SPF) mice, arguing that the signals lacking in GF and Ifnar1−/− mice are linked rather than separately acting. Second, to directly demonstrate that low levels of steady-state IFN-I are required and sufficient to calibrate cDC responsiveness, we injected low doses of IFN-β into ABX-treated mice. IFN-β injections alone did not trigger any TNF release (Figure 5G). While cDCs from ABX-treated mice were unable to produce TNF after stimulation in vivo, cDCs from ABX-treated mice injected with low-dose IFN-β produced normal TNF levels (Figure 5G). These data causally link tonic IFN-I signaling to the calibration of a poised cDC basal state.

    Tonic IFN-I Signals Instruct a Basal cDC State Permissive for CD8+ T Cell Priming

    We wondered whether the propensity of cDCs to prime CD8+ T cells during steady state may also be controlled by pDC-produced IFN-I. To address whether IFNAR signaling is required in the Ag-presenting cDC itself or if a lack of IFNAR in bystander cells dominantly inhibits cDC function in trans, we generated three sets of mixed bone marrow chimeric mice by reconstituting lethally irradiated wild-type hosts with an equal mixture of bone marrow cells from (1) Ifnar1−/− DIETER (CD45.2) and Ifnar1+/+ (CD45.1) mice (restricting IFNAR deficiency to Ag-presenting cDCs), (2) Ifnar1+/+ DIETER (CD45.2) and Ifnar1−/− (CD45.1) (restricting IFNAR deficiency to cDCs that cannot present the model Ag), and (3) of Ifnar1+/+ DIETER (CD45.2) and Ifnar1+/+ mice (CD45.1) (as controls). Inducing Ag presentation on Ifnar1+/+ cDCs after depletion of CD4+ T cells led to robust priming of functional, IFN-γ-producing CD8+ T cells, regardless of the IFNAR status of bystander cells (Figures 6A and 6B). In these chimeras, primed CD8+ T cells were derived in equal proportions from IFNAR-proficient and -deficient T cells, suggesting that direct IFN-I signals to CD8+ T cells are not necessary for T cell priming (Figure S6A). Strikingly, priming of CD8+ T cells was absent when IFNAR-deficiency was restricted to Ag-presenting DIETER cDCs (Figures 6A and 6B). These data demonstrate that tonic IFN-I produced by pDCs act in cis on the Ag-presenting cDC to program a basal state permissive for the priming of T cells at steady state.
    To directly link tonic IFN-I signaling in cDCs to the reduced priming of CD8+ T cells in GF mice, we injected ABX-treated DIETER mice with low doses of IFN-β. ABX-treated DIETER mice that received low-dose IFN-β showed expansion of Ag-specific CD8+ T cells to an extent similar to mice that did not receive ABX treatment (Figure 6C). Importantly, injection of IFN-β could not rescue T cell priming in chimeras where IFNAR deficiency was restricted to model Ag-presenting cDCs (Figure S6B). We wondered whether the depletion of CD4+ T cells is linked to higher expression of IFN-I, but we did not find any upregulation of IFN-β reporter activity (Figures S6C and S6D). Thus, tonic IFN-I signaling in cis is required and sufficient to program a poised cDC state permissive for the priming of CD8+ T cells at steady state.
    It has recently been described that splenic cDCs isolated from Ifnar1−/− mice have an impaired Ag-presentation capacity (Zietara et al., 2009
    85.
    Zietara, N. ∙ Łyszkiewicz, M. ∙ Gekara, N. ...
    Absence of IFN-beta impairs antigen presentation capacity of splenic dendritic cells via down-regulation of heat shock protein 70
    J. Immunol. 2009; 183:1099-1109
    Crossref
    Scopus (32)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We quantified the amount of LCMV GP33–41 peptide presented on cDCs isolated from the spleen of Ifnar1+/+ DIETER or Ifnar1−/− DIETER mice using P14 TCR transgenic mice (recognizing GP33–41 when presented on H2-Db) bred to Nur77GFP reporter mice. T cells from Nur77GFP mice express GFP proportional to the strength of TCR ligation and therefore faithfully report the number of MHC-I:peptide complexes encountered on Ag-presenting cells (Moran et al., 2011
    49.
    Moran, A.E. ∙ Holzapfel, K.L. ∙ Xing, Y. ...
    T cell receptor signal strength in Treg and iNKT cell development demonstrated by a novel fluorescent reporter mouse
    J. Exp. Med. 2011; 208:1279-1289
    Crossref
    Scopus (775)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). No difference in reporter gene expression in P14 T cells stimulated by Ifnar1+/+ DIETER or Ifnar1−/− DIETER cDCs was detected, demonstrating that the lack of priming of CD8+ T cells by steady-state cDCs is not due to reduced Ag presentation (Figure S6E). We wondered if other genes associated with T cell activation (i.e., co-stimulatory molecules or NF-κB regulators) (Probst et al., 2014
    59.
    Probst, H.C. ∙ Muth, S. ∙ Schild, H.
    Regulation of the tolerogenic function of steady-state DCs
    Eur. J. Immunol. 2014; 44:927-933
    Crossref

    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) were altered in expression in GF or Ifnar1−/− cDCs, but we did not find significant changes in expression of such genes in cDC1 and cDC2 (Figure 6D). Verification by flow cytometry did also not reveal any robust differences in line with a previous report (Chinen et al., 2010
    14.
    Chinen, T. ∙ Volchkov, P.Y. ∙ Chervonsky, A.V. ...
    A critical role for regulatory T cell-mediated control of inflammation in the absence of commensal microbiota
    J. Exp. Med. 2010; 207:2323-2330
    Crossref
    Scopus (107)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Thus, the decreased priming of CD8+ T cells by Ag-presenting cDCs deprived of IFN-I signals cannot be simply explained by a reduction in “signal 1” or “signal 2.”

    cDCs Deprived of IFN-I Signals Cannot Prime T Cell Responses following CD40 Stimulation

    Ligation of CD40 is a strong activating stimulus for cDCs, which is illustrated by the induction of a strong CD8+ T cell response in DIETER mice without the need to deplete CD4+ T cells (Probst et al., 2003
    58.
    Probst, H.C. ∙ Lagnel, J. ∙ Kollias, G. ...
    Inducible transgenic mice reveal resting dendritic cells as potent inducers of CD8+ T cell tolerance
    Immunity. 2003; 18:713-720
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (270)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We wondered if the profound inability of cDCs in Ifnar1−/− DIETER mice to prime Ag-specific CD8+ T cells at the steady state could be overcome by direct triggering of CD40 on cDCs. We generated two sets of mixed bone marrow chimeric mice. Irradiated wild-type mice were reconstituted with an equal mixture of bone marrow from wild-type mice (CD45.1) and (1) from Ifnar1+/+ DIETER (CD45.2), or (2) from Ifnar1−/− DIETER mice (CD45.2). In these chimeras, wild-type (CD45.1) cDCs (and other MPhs) will be able to unleash the full inflammatory program (“signal 3”) induced by CD40 ligation. While CD40 ligation led to a profound priming of Ag-specific CD8+ T cells in Ifnar1+/+ DIETER:wild-type chimeras, we found virtually no expansion of CD8+ T cells in Ifnar1−/− DIETER:wild-type chimeras (Figure 6E). These surprising data demonstrate a crucial need for microbiota-dependent IFN-I signaling in cDCs during steady state for the programming of a basal cDC regulome, the lack of which cannot be simply overcome by direct triggering of cDCs and concurrent provision of inflammatory cytokines unleashed by CD40 stimulation.

    Microbiota and IFN-I Instruct the Epigenetic Basal State of cDCs

    It was striking that the deprivation of cDCs from tonic IFN-I signals could not be overcome by direct stimulation in an inflammatory environment. We had previously shown that microbiota affects chromatin states of cDCs (Ganal et al., 2012
    22.
    Ganal, S.C. ∙ Sanos, S.L. ∙ Kallfass, C. ...
    Priming of natural killer cells by nonmucosal mononuclear phagocytes requires instructive signals from commensal microbiota
    Immunity. 2012; 37:171-186
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (386)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We performed chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) for H3K4me3 (marking all transcriptionally active and poised genes) (Santos-Rosa et al., 2002
    65.
    Santos-Rosa, H. ∙ Schneider, R. ∙ Bannister, A.J. ...
    Active genes are tri-methylated at K4 of histone H3
    Nature. 2002; 419:407-411
    Crossref
    Scopus (1697)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and H3K27me3 (a major mark of transcriptionally inactive genes) (Schwartz and Pirrotta, 2007
    68.
    Schwartz, Y.B. ∙ Pirrotta, V.
    Polycomb silencing mechanisms and the management of genomic programmes
    Nat. Rev. Genet. 2007; 8:9-22
    Crossref
    Scopus (734)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) using chromatin from GF, Ifnar1−/−, and control SPF cDCs isolated at steady state. H3K4me3 peaks present in control (SPF) cDCs were missing on 274 genes of GF cDCs and on 308 genes of Ifnar1−/− cDCs. Of these genes lacking H3K4me3, 63% (174) were common to cDCs from GF and Ifnar1−/− mice. PCA based on the genome-wide peak intensities revealed that the overall H3K4me3 pattern observed in GF and Ifnar1−/− cDCs was more similar than when these were compared to control mice (Figures 7A and S7A). To obtain an understanding of the functional annotations of genes that were marked with H3K4me3 in control mice, but not in GF or Ifnar1−/− mice (Figure 7B, marked in red), we submitted these genes to DAVID for GO term enrichment analysis that returned GO terms related to immune responses (Figure 7C), including various IFN-I genes, chemokines, and antimicrobial proteins (Table S2). By directly analyzing overall H3K4me3 occupancy at all ISG promoters (Figure 7D) and marking with H3K4me3 on specific ISG promoters (Figure S7B), we identified a significant reduction, consistent with the reduced steady-state expression of ISGs in GF and Ifnar1−/− cDCs. Collectively, the genome-wide data from H3K4me3 ChIP-seq further supported our model that microbiota-driven, steady-state IFN-I signals are an important component of the machinery instructing the poised basal state of cDCs.

    Microbiota and IFN-I Control the Metabolic Basal State of cDCs

    We next focused on H3K27me3, a principal inhibitory mark associated with heterochromatin, and submitted the top 1,000 differentially H3K27me3-marked genes common to GF and Ifnar1−/− cDCs for DAVID pathway analysis. In line with our transcriptional data (Figure 3F), genes associated with mitochondrial (e.g., oxidative phosphorylation, electron transport chain, and TCA cycle), cytosolic (e.g., glycolysis), and nuclear metabolic processes (e.g., PPAR signaling) were enriched for the inhibitory H3K27me3 mark in GF and Ifnar1−/− cDCs (Figure 7E).
    To obtain insights into metabolic function of cDCs from GF or Ifnar1−/− mice, we analyzed the mitochondrial membrane potential using MitoTracker Red CMXRos, a cell permeable probe, the uptake of which is directly correlated with mitochondrial membrane potential. MitoTracker uptake was significantly reduced in cDCs isolated from GF and Ifnar1−/− mice (Figure 7F). Mitochondrial mass and inner membrane surface was interrogated using 10-N-nonyl acridine orange (NAO), which is integrated into the inner mitochondrial membrane independent of membrane potential. Interestingly, NAO uptake was also reduced in GF and Ifnar1−/− cDCs (Figure 7G). These data prompted us to assess mitochondrial structure of cDCs using transmission electron microscopy (Figure 7H). Specifically, we quantified number, density, size, and form of mitochondria, all of which were not significantly different between the various groups of cDCs (Figures S7C–S7E). However, mitochondria of GF and Ifnar1−/− cDCs had looser cristae and a wider intermembrane space (Figure 7I) that has been previously associated in T cells with less efficient electron transfer chain activity, reduced membrane potential, and mitochondrial function (Klein Geltink et al., 2017
    37.
    Klein Geltink, R.I. ∙ O’Sullivan, D. ∙ Corrado, M. ...
    Mitochondrial Priming by CD28
    Cell. 2017; 171:385-397
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (210)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).
    We directly investigated the basal metabolic state of freshly isolated splenic cDCs from GF and Ifnar1−/− mice using extracellular flux analysis. We first assessed mitochondrial function by measuring the oxygen consumption rate (OCR), an indicator of oxidative phosphorylation. Both GF and Ifnar1−/− cDCs had a considerably lower baseline OCR compared to cDCs from control mice (Figure 7J). While incubation of control cDCs with FCCP (an uncoupler allowing free flow of electrons through the respiratory chain) resulted in a marked enhancement of OCR, the respiratory capacity of cDCs from Ifnar1−/− and GF mice could only be boosted to a much lesser extent. Accordingly, the spare respiratory capacity (SRC) of cDCs from GF and Ifnar1−/− mice was low (Figure 7K). SRC is the extra mitochondrial capacity available in a cell to produce energy under conditions of increased work or stress thought to be important for long-term cell survival and function. Extracellular acidification rate (ECAR) of cDCs obtained from GF and Ifnar1−/− mice, which is an indicator of glycolysis, was not much different between control cDCs and cDCs from GF and Ifnar1−/− mice (Figure S7F).
    Collectively, our data demonstrate that microbiota-controlled, tonic IFN-I signaling in cDCs at steady state instructs a poised functional state. Such basal state of cDCs is characterized by a distinct transcriptional, chromatin, and metabolic program that is required so that cDCs can effectively respond to microbial stimulation. This beneficial function comes at a price, because the same signals program cDCs so that they can present harmless peripheral antigens and prime unwanted T cell responses, an adverse event usually blunted by mechanisms of peripheral tolerance. Removal of tonic IFN-I signaling or of IFN-I-producing pDCs makes cDCs entirely unresponsive even when triggered directly in an inflammatory environment.

    Discussion

    Recognition of pathogens via PRRs expressed by cDCs leading to their activation and maturation is the central process that links innate immune recognition to Ag-specific adaptive immunity, a powerful mechanism to protect vertebrate hosts against infections (Janeway, 1989
    33.
    Janeway, Jr., C.A.

In the absence of microbiota, cDCs as well as other subsets of MPhs cannot appropriately engage an activation program upon stimulation, leading to higher susceptibility to some virus infections (Abt et al., 2012; Galindo-Villegas et al., 2012; Ganal et al., 2012; Kane et al., 2011; Wilks and Golovkina, 2012

    We found that the commensal microbiota is the major regulator of steady-state IFN-I expression, and we identified microbiota-controlled tonic IFN-I signaling in cDCs as the major “instructor” of the cDC basal state.     ), the regulation of steady-state IFN-I by microbial communities may be of relevance for the pathomechanisms and therapies of these diseases. Collectively, our data identify a new level of cDC programming during steady state that we refer to as cDC “instruction.” cDCs are instructed by long-range actions of steady-state IFN-I levels that are produced by pDCs upon sensing of the indigenous microbiota. Steady-state IFN-I instruct a specific epigenomic and metabolic regulome poising cDCs for responsiveness to pathogen encounter. Such a beneficial biological function comes with a trade-off, that cDCs in such a poised state can prime unwanted T cell responses, a peril that is countered by the barriers of peripheral tolerance.

    Data and Code Availability

    The datasets generated during this study (i.e., RNA-seq and ChIP-seq analyses) are available through the EBI database ‘ArrayExpress’ under the accession numbers EMBL-EBI: E-MTAB-5190 (RNA-seq of unstimulated and LPS stimulated cDC from SPF, GF and Ifnar1−/− mice; Figures 2 and 5), EMBL-EBI: E-MTAB-5234 (ChIP-seq for H3K4Me3 and H3K27me3 of unstimulated cDC from SPF, GF and Ifnar1−/− mice), EMBL-EBI: E-MTAB-8882 (RNA-seq of unstimulated cDC from SPF, GF and Ifnar1−/− mice; Figure 3) and EMBL-EBI: E-MTAB-8883 (RNA-seq of unstimulated cDC1 and cDC2 from SPF, GF and Ifnar1−/− mice; Figures 4, 6, and S2F).

    Cell lines and bacterial strains

    Murine subcutaneous connective tissue-derived L-929 cells (ATCC CCL-1) were cultured in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 2 mM L-Glutamine, 50 U/ml Penicillin, 50 μg/ml Streptomycin, 100 μg/ml Gentamicin, 10 mM HEPES, 1x MEM non-essential amino acid solution and maintained at 37°C, 5% CO2. For VSV bioassay L-929 cells were seeded into 96-well culture plates in DMEM supplemented with 5% FBS at a density of 1.5 × 104 cells per well as described in Ganal et al. (2012)

    Method Details

    Antibiotics Treatment

    To diminish the intestinal commensal microflora, mice were treated with antibiotics provided via the drinking water 1.0 mg/ml gentamicin (Sigma-Aldrich), 1.0 mg/ml metronidazole (Sigma-Aldrich), 1.0 mg/ml vancomycin (Hexal) and 1.0 mg/ml cefoxitin (Santa Cruz). Mice were treated with antibiotics two weeks before the experiment and treatment was continued for the duration of the experiment. To verify elimination of bacteria, fresh feces isolated directly from the colon was dissolved in PBS (0.1 mg feces per ml PBS) and dissolved using a FastPrep-24 homogenizer (MP Bio). The dissolved feces was plated in serial tenfold dilutions on Columbia Blood Agar, McConkey Agar and Schädler’s Agar. Colombia Blood Agar and McConkey Agar Plates were incubated at 37°C for 24 hours. Schädler’s Agar Plates were incubated under anaerobic conditions for 48 hours at 37°C using airtight containers (Merck) and GasPak EZ pouches (Becton Dickinson). Anaerobic conditions were verified using anaerobic indicator stripes (Becton Dickinson). Colony Forming Units (CFU) were counted and calculated as CFU per g feces.

    Recolonization of germ-free mice

    E. coli JM83 monocolonization

    Escherichia coli JM83 was cultured overnight in LB medium at 37°C, shaking at 200 rpm (Hapfelmeier et al., 2010
    25.
    Hapfelmeier, S. ∙ Lawson, M.A. ∙ Slack, E. ...
    Reversible microbial colonization of germ-free mice reveals the dynamics of IgA immune responses
    Science. 2010; 328:1705-1709
    Crossref
    Scopus (614)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). To prepare gavage solutions, bacteria were centrifuged for 10 min at 4000 x g and washed twice with sterile PBS. A dose of 1010 CFU was resuspended in 500 μL of sterile PBS and administered to germ-free mice by oral gavage. Mice were kept for 4 weeks in order to allow for stable colonization before analysis.

    sDMDMm2 colonization

    Mice colonized with the stable Defined Moderately Diverse Mouse microbiota 2 (sDMDMm2) were born to sDMDMm2 colonized dams and raised under this defined colonization status (Uchimura et al., 2016
    79.
    Uchimura, Y. ∙ Wyss, M. ∙ Brugiroux, S. ...
    Complete Genome Sequences of 12 Species of Stable Defined Moderately Diverse Mouse Microbiota 2
    Genome Announc. 2016; 4:e00951-16
    Crossref
    Scopus (39)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).
    Generation of bone marrow chimeras
    Bone marrow was isolated by flushing tibiae and femora of donor mice with PBS. Bone marrow cells were depleted of T cells using anti-mouse pan-T Dynabeads (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) according to the manufacturer’s instruction. The cells were then mixed at the indicated ratios and 2-3 × 106 cells were injected intravenously (i.v.) into mice that had been lethally (9.5 Gy) irradiated using a 137Cs source. Mice received BORGAL (1 mg/ml sulfadoxin and 0.2 mg/ml trimethoprim) in the drinking water for 3 weeks and were rested 6-8 weeks after transplantation before they were used in experiments. Equal take of bone marrow-derived cells from different origin in mixed chimeras was verified by flow cytometric analysis of CD45.1 and CD45.2 expression on blood T lymphocytes. Only animals with a close to 1:1 ratio of CD45.1+ and CD45.2+ of leukocytes were included in the experiments.
    Induction of Ag presentation in DIETER mice
    Ag presentation by steady-state cDC was induced in vivo by injecting DIETER mice or DIETER bone marrow chimeras i.p. with 2 mg tamoxifen (TAM) as described before (Probst et al., 2003
    58.
    Probst, H.C. ∙ Lagnel, J. ∙ Kollias, G. ...
    Inducible transgenic mice reveal resting dendritic cells as potent inducers of CD8+ T cell tolerance
    Immunity. 2003; 18:713-720
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (270)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). CD4+ T cells were depleted one day before TAM administration by injection of 0.5 mg GK1.5 i.v. pDC were depleted by injection of 0.5 mg PDCA-1 antibody on days −2, −1 and 1 (mAb 927, kind gift of M.Colonna). Priming of endogenous, GP33-41/Db- specific CD8+ T cells was measured 7 or 8 days after TAM injection by tetramer staining.
    Peptides
    LCMV-derived peptide GP33–41 (KAVYNFATM, H-2Db) was kindly provided by Dr. Stefanovic, Interfaculty Institute for Cell Biology, Department of Immunology, University of Tübingen, Germany.
    In vivo and in vitro stimulation of myeloid cells
    For in vivo stimulation, 50 μg ultrapure LPS from E. coli O111:B4 (Sigma-Aldrich), 100 μg poly(I:C) (HMW, InvivoGen) or 75 μg anti-CD40 (clone FGK4.5, BioXCell) were diluted in 200 μl PBS and mice were injected intraperitoneally (i.p.). Purified cDC or bulk spleen cultures were activated in vitro with 1 μg/ml LPS for the indicated time in the presence of 5 μg/ml Brefeldin A.
    Determination of serum cytokine levels
    TNF was measured by ELISA (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. IFN-I concentrations were determined by VSV bioassay (Ganal et al., 2012
    22.
    Ganal, S.C. ∙ Sanos, S.L. ∙ Kallfass, C. ...

    ).
    Leukocyte isolation from lymphoid organs
    Spleens, peripheral or mesenteric lymph nodes, or Peyer’s patches were removed, first homogenized with a scissor and digested with collagenase II (Worthington, Lakewood, NJ) and DNase I (Sigma- Aldrich, St. Louis, MO) for 30 min at 37°C followed by incubation with 10 mM EDTA for 10 min at 37°C to dissociate DC-T cell clusters. Erythrocytes were removed by osmotic lysis by incubating the pelleted cells with 1 mL of red cell lysis buffer (RCLB) for 1 min on ice or with a 15% Optiprep density gradient.
    Antibodies and flow cytometric analysis
    Antibodies against mouse CD40 (clone FGK4.5), mouse CD4 (clone GK1.5) and rat IgG2b, κ, isotype control antibodies (clone SFR-8B6, specific for HLA-Bw6) were purified from hybridoma culture supernatant using protein G Sepharose (Genscript, Piscataway, NJ). Tetrameric peptide-MHC complexes were generated and staining was performed as described previously (Altman et al., 1996; Probst et al., 2003
    3.
    Altman, J.D. ∙ Moss, P.A.H. ∙ Goulder, P.J.R. ...

    ). Fluorochrome-coupled antibodies for flow cytometry were purchased as indicated in the Key Resources Table. Single cell suspensions were incubated for 20 min with 0.5 μg/ml anti-CD16/CD32 (clone 2.4G2) to block Fc-receptors followed by staining with fluorochrome-coupled antibodies for 20 min at 4°C in FACS buffer (PBS 1% BSA, 2 mM EDTA). Erythrocytes were lysed using Red Cell Lysis Buffer (RCLB). Flow cytometry analyses was performed following the recommendations in Cossarizza et al. (2019)

    Cossarizza, A. ∙ Chang, H.D. ∙ Radbruch, A. ...

    . Samples were analyzed on either a LSR-II, a FACSCanto II or a Fortessa X20 Cytometer (Becton Dickinson, Mountain View, CA) and data were analyzed with FlowJo Analysis Software (Tree Star Inc, Ashland, OR). For sorting of splenic cDCs, cells were pre-enriched for CD11c+ cells using CD11c MACS beads (Miltenyi) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. To purify various leukocyte populations and stroma cells from Ifnb1+/Δβ-luc mice, spleens were enzymatically digested as described above and leukocytes were separated using a 15% Optiprep density gradient. Cells were stained with the respective fluorescent antibodies. Cell sorting was performed on an ARIA II or an ARIA III Fusion cell sorter (Becton Dickinson) based on a published strategy to analyze the splenic myeloid compartment in mice (Rose et al., 2012

    Rose, S. ∙ Misharin, A. ∙ Perlman, H.

    ).
    Intracellular cytokine staining
    After cell surface staining, cells were fixed with 2% paraformaldehyde, permeabilized with 0.1% saponin (ROTH, Karlsruhe, Germany) in FACS buffer and stained intracellularly for the respective cytokines. In order to detect IFN-γ produced by Ag-specific T cells in DIETER mice, cells were incubated for 6 h at 37°C with 10−6 M peptide GP33-41, 0.5 μg/ml PMA (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO) plus 0.05 μg/ml ionomycin (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO) or with medium alone, in the presence of 5 μg/ml Brefeldin A (Sigma-Aldrich). For detection of TNF produced by in vivo or ex vivo stimulated cDC, cells were fixed/permeabilized after cell surface staining as described above, followed by intracellular TNF staining for 2 h.
    Quantification of antigen presentation by cDC
    For quantification of Ag presentation by cDC, Nur77GFP reporter mice that express GFP proportionally to the strength of TCR ligation were used (Moran et al., 2011
    49.
    Moran, A.E. ∙ Holzapfel, K.L. ∙ Xing, Y. ...
    T cell receptor signal strength in Treg and iNKT cell development demonstrated by a novel fluorescent reporter mouse
    J. Exp. Med. 2011; 208:1279-1289
    Crossref
    Scopus (775)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). 48 h after the Cre-mediated induction of Ag presentation in DIETER mice, spleens were removed and treated with collagenase II, DNase I and EDTA as described above. cDCs were enriched using an OptiPrep gradient (AxisShield, Dundee, UK) as described resulting in a purity of ∼30% CD11chighMHC-IIhigh cells. DCs were cultured in serial dilutions for 16 h with 5x103 purified CD8+ Nur77GFP x TCR327 (P14) T cells. Induction of GFP expression in Nur77GFP x TCR327 (P14) CD8+ T cells was analyzed by flow cytometry.
    Bioluminescence Measurements
    For in vivo measurement of luciferase activity, mice were injected i.p. with luciferin (Caliper) at a final concentration of 150 mg/kg body weight. Within 30 min, whole body imaging was performed or mice were sacrificed and organs were individually analyzed with a Caliper Life Science IVIS Spectrum camera. For ex vivo measurement of luciferase activity of Ifnb1+/Δβ-luc mice, leukocytes were isolated and digested as described above and lysed in passive lysis buffer (Promega). Spleen stroma cells were lysed in passive lysis buffer (Luciferase Assay System, Promega) using a potter homogenizer. Lysates were centrifuged for 30 s at 16000 x g and luciferase activity in supernatants was measured in a single tube Luminometer (Turner Designs) using Luciferase Assay Substrate (Luciferase Assay System, Promega). For ex vivo luminometric analysis shown in Figure S6C, the indicated organs were removed, homogenized and lysed in Luciferase Cell Culture Lysis Buffer (Promega) via Lysing Matrix A on a FastPrep-24 (MP Biomedicals). Luciferase activity was measured in a Sirius Tube Luminometer (Berthold Technologies) by the single Luciferase Assay System (Promega).
    Extracellular flux analysis
    For real-time measurement of OCR and ECAR, sort purified splenic cDC were rested for 3 h until adherent to a XFe96 microplate. Media was exchanged with un-supplemented XF Assay Medium and analyzed with an XFe96 Extracellular Flux Analyzer (Agilent Seahorse). Four consecutive measurements were obtained under basal conditions followed by the addition of 10 mM glucose, 1 μM oligomycin, which inhibits the mitochondrial ATP synthase, 1.5 μM triflouromethoxy phenylhydrazone (FCCP), which uncouples ATP synthesis from oxygen consumption and a combination of 100 nM rotenone plus 1 μM antimycin A, which inhibit the electron transport chain by blocking complex I and III, respectively. All chemicals used for these assays were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. SRC is calculated as the difference between basal OCR and the maximal OCR after the addition of FCCP.
    Mitochondrial Stainings
    Bulk splenic cultures were stained with either 5 μM Nonyl Acridine Orange (Invitrogen) or 100 nM Mitotracker CMXRos (Invitrogen) for 15 min at 37°C, 5% CO2 in serum-free RPMI medium. Cells were subsequently washed and stained with fluorescent antibodies before they were analyzed by flow cytometry.
    Transmission electron microscopy
    Isolated cells were fixed on glass coverslips in 4% paraformaldehyde and 1% glutaraldehyde (EM Grade, Sigma-Aldrich) in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4 (PB). Following fixation, samples were washed in PB and post fixed in 1% osmium tetroxide. After extensive washing in 0.1 M PB, samples were contrasted using 1% uranyl acetate in 70% ethanol for 1 h, dehydrated in an ascending ethanol series, followed by propylen oxide and finally embedded in epoxy resin (Durcupan, Roth, Germany). Ultrathin sections were cut using an UC6 Leica ultramicrotome and imaged using a Philips CM100 Transmisson Electron Microscope (TEM). Quantitative image analysis was performed using Olympus ITEM software.
    Quantification of mRNA expression
    Cells were resuspended in Trizol reagent (Invitrogen) and RNA was extracted according to the manufacturer’s instructions. For DNA removal, the RNA was treated with the TURBO DNA-free kit (Invitrogen). The RNA concentration was measured using a Qubit 2.0 Fluorimeter (Invitrogen) or a NanoDrop spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Subsequently, the isolated RNA amounts were normalized and the same amount of RNA was used in every reaction (up to 2 μg total RNA per reaction). RNA was reverse transcribed into cDNA using the High Capacity cDNA Reverse Transcription Kit (Applied Biosystems) according to the manufacturer’s protocol. Quantitative Real-Time PCR was performed in 384 well plates and run on a QuantStudio 5 Real-Time PCR System (Applied Biosystems). Primers (Sigma-Aldrich) were used at a final concentration of 400 nM in SYBR Green PCR Master Mix (Applied Biosystems). All reactions were performed in duplicates or triplicates and gene expression was normalized to the expression of the house keeping gene hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase 1 (Hprt1). Primer sequences used for qRT-PCR are listed in Table S3.
    RNA Sequencing Analysis
    RNA-seq analyses shown in Figures 2, 5, S2, and S5 were performed using 2 biological replicates. Total RNA was prepared from sort-purified cDC (as in Figure S2A, step 1-7) using Trizol (Invitrogen) and isopropanol precipitation with linear polyacrylamide (GenElute-LPA, Sigma-Aldrich) as a carrier. The RNA concentration was measured using a Qubit 2.0 Fluorimeter (Invitrogen) and the RNA quality was measured on a Bioanalyzer 2100 (Agilent Genomics). 10 ng of total RNA was subsequently used to prepare RNA-Seq library by using the TruSeq RNA sample prep kit (Illumina) according to manufacturer’s instructions. Paired-end RNA sequencing was performed on a HiSeq 2500 (Illumina).
    RNA-seq analysis shown in Figures 3 and S3 was performed using 3 biological replicates. RNA was isolated using the RNeasy plus micro kit (QIAGEN). RNA quantity was assessed by Qubit 2.0 using HS RNA assay kit, quality was determined by Bioanalyzer 2100 (Agilent) using RNA pico chip. Barcoded mRNA seq libraries were prepared from 100 ng of total RNA (RIN > 8) using a NEBnext poly(A) mRNA Magnetic Isolation Module and NEBnext UltraII lib prep kit for Illumina (New England Biosciences) according to the manual. All quality controls were done using Invitrogen’s Qubit HS assay and fragment size was determined on Agilent’s 2100 Bioanalyzer HS DNA assay. Single-end RNA sequencing (59nt) was performed on a HiSeq 2500 (Illumina). Barcoded RNA-seq libraries were onboard clustered using HiSeq® Rapid SR Cluster Kit v2 using 8pM and 59bps were sequenced on the Illumina HiSeq 2500 using HiSeq® Rapid SBS Kit v2 (59 Cycle). The raw output data of the HiSeq was preprocessed according to the Illumina standard protocol.
    RNA-seq analysis shown in Figures 4 and S4 was performed using 4 biological replicates For RNA-seq analyses of splenic cDC1 and cDC2 (sorted as shown in Figure S2A, step 1-8), total RNA was prepared from sort-purified cDC1 and cDC2 (for each sample 3 individual mice were pooled) using Trizol reagent (Invitrogen) in combination with the miRNeasy Micro Kit (QIAGEN) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. For RNA quality validation samples were analyzed using the Fragment Analyzer System and the HS RNA 15nt Kit (Agilent). Only RNA samples with an RNA Quality Number ≥ 9 were selected for sequencing. For poly-A-dependent cDNA synthesis and a first amplification step 10 ng of total RNA was used as input in the Smart-Seq v4 mRNA Ultra Low Input RNA Kit (Clontech) and processed according to the manufacturer’s instructions. After quality control (HS NGS Fragment Kit (1-6000bp), Agilent) and concentration measurement (Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit, Invitrogen), 1 ng of the purified cDNA was used for tagmentation and library completion with the Nextera XT library preparation kit (Illumina). In the following, 2x75nt paired-end sequencing was performed on an Illumina NextSeq 500.
    Sequenced reads were aligned to the mouse genome (NCBI37/mm9) with Tophat 2.0.9 (Kim et al., 2013

    Google Scholar
    ) was performed for GO terms classified as biological processes. An enrichment map was created in Cytoscape (v3.7.2) (Shannon et al., 2003
    69.
    Shannon, P. ∙ Markiel, A. ∙ Ozier, O. ...
    Cytoscape: a software environment for integrated models of biomolecular interaction networks
    Genome Res. 2003; 13:2498-2504
    Crossref
    Scopus (32549)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) using all significantly enriched GO terms (FDR < 0.05) with a gene set size between 10-1000. Overlap was used as metric and the cutoff was set to 1. Clustering was performed using AutoAnnotate (v1.3.2) (Kucera et al., 2016
    39.
    Kucera, M. ∙ Isserlin, R. ∙ Arkhangorodsky, A. ...
    AutoAnnotate: A Cytoscape app for summarizing networks with semantic annotations
    F1000Res. 2016; 5:1717
    Crossref
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with overlap used as edge weight values. Normalized gene counts from DESeq2 were used as expression dataset for GSEA analysis (v4.0.1 with MSigDB v7.0) (Subramanian et al., 2005
    74.
    Subramanian, A. ∙ Tamayo, P. ∙ Mootha, V.K. ...
    Gene set enrichment analysis: a knowledge-based approach for interpreting genome-wide expression profiles
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2005; 102:15545-15550
    Crossref
    Scopus (33620)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and the Chip platform for conversion of mouse to human annotations was derived from MGI vertebrate homology reports. Permutation was set to gene_set and gene set size limits was set to 10-1000.
    Chromatin Immunoprecipitation
    Highly purified splenic cDCs were fixed in 1.0% formaldehyde (Sigma). The fixing reaction was quenched by the addition of 1 M glycine. Cell lysis was performed in ChIP lysis buffer. The pellet was then resuspended in sonication buffer following sonification in a Bioruptor UCD-300 (Diagenode) for 20 cycles at high intensity. The lysates were cleared and transferred into new tubes. A portion of the sample serving as input was frozen at −80°C until further use. The antibody specific against the protein of interest was added and incubated overnight. Blocked protein-A-beads were added and extensively washed. The samples were eluted by adding ChIP elution buffer following decrosslinking at 65°C overnight. RNaseA (PeqLab) and proteinase K (PeqLab) were added. Subsequently, 5 M NaCl was added to the samples before DNA was purified with the PCR Purification Kit (QIAGEN). The samples were stored at −80°C until further use.
    ChIP-seq and Analysis
    All ChIP-seq analyses were performed using 2 biological replicates. Raw data from replicate measurements are publically available from the EBI ArrayExpress repository. ChIP DNA was prepared as described above and was subsequently used to prepare ChIP-seq library by using NEBNext® Ultra DNA Library Prep Kit (Illumina) according to manufacturer’s instructions. Paired-end RNA sequencing was performed on a HiSeq 2500 (Illumina). Sequenced reads were aligned to the mouse genome (NCBI37/mm9) with Tophat 2.0.9 (Kim et al., 2013
    36.
    Kim, D. ∙ Pertea, G. ∙ Trapnell, C. ...
    TopHat2: accurate alignment of transcriptomes in the presence of insertions, deletions and gene fusions
    Genome Biol. 2013; 14:R36
    Crossref
    Scopus (9645)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and Bowtie2 (v2.2.4) (Langmead and Salzberg, 2012
    40.
    Langmead, B. ∙ Salzberg, S.L.
    Fast gapped-read alignment with Bowtie 2
    Nat. Methods. 2012; 9:357-359
    Crossref
    Scopus (33805)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Uniquely mapped reads were used to calculate gene expression. RefSeq gene database (mm9) was downloaded from the UCSC genome browser for ChIP-seq analysis. Peak calling was performed with MACS2 (v.2.1.1) (Zhang et al., 2008
    84.
    Zhang, Y. ∙ Liu, T. ∙ Meyer, C.A. ...
    Model-based analysis of ChIP-Seq (MACS)
    Genome Biol. 2008; 9:R137
    Crossref
    Scopus (10897)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and visualization of results was performed using DeepTools (v.2.5.0) (Ramírez et al., 2016
    61.
    Ramírez, F. ∙ Ryan, D.P. ∙ Grüning, B. ...
    deepTools2: a next generation web server for deep-sequencing data analysis
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2016; 44:W160-5
    Crossref
    Scopus (1768)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).

    Quantification and Statistical Analysis

    Statistical parameters including the exact value of n, the definition of center, dispersion and precision measures (mean ± SD) and statistical significance are reported in the Figures and Figure Legends. Data was judged to be statistically significant when p < 0.05 by two-tailed Student’s t test or One-way Anova with Bonferroni’s multiple comparisons test. In figures, asterisks denote statistical significance as calculated by Student’s t test or One-way Anova with Bonferroni’s multiple comparisons test, ∗ p < 0.05; ∗∗ p < 0.01; ∗∗∗ p < 0.001, ∗∗∗∗ p < 0.0001). Statistical analysis was performed in R version 3.1.2 or GraphPad Prism.

    You may choose not to allow some types of cookies. However, blocking some types may impact your experience of our site and the services we are able to offer. See the different category headings below to find out more or change your settings.

    Manage Consent Preferences

    Strictly Necessary Cookies

    Always active

    These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

    Functional Cookies

    These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.

    Performance Cookies

    These cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site.

    Targeting Cookies

    These cookies may be set through our site by our advertising partners. They may be used by those companies to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant adverts on other sites. If you do not allow these cookies, you will experience less targeted advertising.
